title: Are private school teachers generally happier than public school teachers? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have taught in both public and private schools. From my experience, private school teachers are “happier.” I currently teach at a private, Catholic preK-12 school where I make about $8k less per year than I made teaching at a public school 5 years ago. The difference in work environment is worth the $8k and more for the following reasons: I have motivated students who come from families that value education. I rarely have issues with behavior, and if I do, I have the support of parents. I spend my time teaching, not redirecting disruptive students.Small class sizes- Our school does offer special education services for mild to moderate disabilities (many private schools do not), and my class sizes are small enough to to afford time and attention to students who need more direct instruction. I’m able to challenge advanced students to go beyond standard curriculum.I have a more flexible schedule and more prep time. I teach writing intensive courses so my administrator has built in more open time in my schedule to accommodate the large amount of grading I must complete.I have more freedom with curriculum. I can develop units and activities aligned with our state’s standards.My coworkers feel the same way I do. They are where they want to be because they are happy and content. Our staff lounge conversations are about our families, upcoming events, and student and alumni accomplishments. We have a positive culture that transcends throughout the students and staff.When I taught public school, I had: More students in each classMore wasted time managing behaviorsMore pointless meetings with administrators whose jobs are to support teachers but somehow manage to make more work for them (curriculum directors, assessment coordinators, intervention coordinators) equals less time to focus on studentsNew curriculum approximately every 3 years that includes the latest educational buzzwords. Really, does grammar change that much in 3 years? There’s money to be made in educational marketing.Coworkers who didn’t like the students much less their jobs. Who wants to have lunch listening to people bitching day after day?

It really depends on where the schools are and what the teachers want in life. I can only speak for the schools in and around Chicago. I teach at a private school, and I have some connections to public school teachers. I’m happiest teaching at a private school, because I’m more interested in work/life balance and flexibility than I’m interested in money. I make less, but have a less stressful job and more flexibility to take time off for my kids if necessary. I’m happier this way. Here are the main differences for teachers: Public school: Much higher salaries and benefits.Harder to get in to. You really need to know someone.A lot of bureaucracy, red-tape, and oversight.Less academic/curriculum freedom.More standardized tests for the students.More documentation.Less work/life time flexibility.Usually, but not always, more challenging students.Usually, but not always, more challenging parents.Usually, but not always, less job security.Private school: Much lower salaries and benefits. Like, 50–60% of what you’d make at a public school around here.Easier to get in to, particularly if you’re still looking for a job in August. Private schools tend to get desperate because teachers break their contract at the last minute because they get “picked up” by a better-paying public school.Much less bureaucracy and oversight.More freedom to teach what you want, how you want, within loose guidelines. When I taught reading, I got to pick all of the novels, the pace, the questions, everything. It was great!Fewer standardized tests for the students.Less documentation.More work/life flexibility.Usually, but not always, more respectful students. Literally the main discipline problem I have to deal with is kids who talk too much.Smaller class sizes! Makes everything easier.Usually, but not always, parents that are on your side and involved with their child’s education. I’m actually Facebook friends with some of my students’ parents. I enjoy talking to them after school.Usually, but not always, a guaranteed job for as long as you want it. I’ve never had a coworker at a private school get fired or fail to get re-hired for another year. Everyone who leaves does so by choice.

My first year of teaching was in a private school (in 1990). The children and parents were absolutely wonderful to work with and I was immensely sad to leave to teach public school. Unfortunately, I was a single person living on my own at the time and I was barely making ends meet on my salary of $9,785 per year! I was literally buying gas for my car with rolls of pennies and change found in my couch cushions. I skipped dinner most nights and I couldn't afford to have a home phone (everyone had landlines then). I had to walk about a half mile to use a payphone if I needed to make a call. My second year of teaching was in public school for a salary of approximately $17,000 per year. Even though that salary was still below poverty level, I felt wealthy because I was able to pay my rent, have a phone, eat three meals a day, and buy gas with actual dollar bills! The negative part of public school teaching was the mixed bag of students and parents. At the private school, my students were very well behaved and their parents were supportive. I was able to teach and accomplish a great deal each day because I wasn’t spending a ton of time on discipline. When I did have to discipline, parents showed their support. Public school was a shock for me with this. I taught in a rather bad area with lots of social problems and getting through the curriculum was difficult. I felt like what I’d accomplish in a day at the private school, it would take about three days to do in public school because of discipline issues. I stayed with public school for the majority of my career only because of the pay issue.

I’m not in NYC. But I don’t know if that makes much of a difference. Happiness is difficult to measure and evaluate. I don’t think one could easily make a case that one leads to greater happiness than the other. Broadly speaking, I do believe that in the USA, private school teachers have a less stress in their lives because of their teaching. In general, private school teachers don’t have to deal with the same levels of defiance, disruption, animosity, resentment, and scorn that public school teachers often must endure relentlessly. I must add a caveat though. When many people think of private school, they usually imagine something that is wealthy , sophisticated, traditional etc…This is often true. However, there are also many private schools that are simply attempting to cater or a niche market. This may lead to other forms of stress. This is not to say that teaching in private schools is easy and stress-free. However, the stress is usually not nearly as relentless, nor as emotional.

It is totally dependent on the person. A person who is generally happy can be happy anywhere. Yes, circumstances contribute greatly to that feeling but those circumstances can happen in private or public schools. Just like in any other business, you might end up with a bad team, mean boss and too much work. So each school system is different and every classroom that you will be in will have its own personality. No teacher can ever say that every year in his or her teaching career has been similar. Every year is so different. Having said that, some basic differences between private and public schools are: Private schools have smaller class sizes compared to Public. If in USA, the numbers would be 15 Vs 30.The pay scales in a private school is much lower than public schools.Public schools are state funded so you will have much more access to amenities.The class makeup in a private school is mostly homogenous and the heterogenous makeup of a public school can prove to be challenging.Usually the academic year of a private school is shorter than public schools.Public schools have unions that protect teacher rights, no such thing in a private school.I hope this helps. Thanks for the A2A.

Thanks for the A2A. This is a difficult question to answer. I only worked in independent (private) schools, so it is hard for me to compare my experience to that of teachers in public schools. I was very happy (for the most part) in the schools in which I taught, but I know a few teachers in other independent schools who do not have as good an experience as I had because of the nature of their school. On the other hand, I know some public school teachers who throughly enjoy their experience, and other who do not and no longer teach. I think the answer is that it depends on the person and the school. Would I have been happy teaching in a public school? Most likely. But maybe not. It is hard to compare the two experiences because the personalities of the individuals and the teaching situations are all different.

Private school teachers probably are happier in general, although they are often very poorly paid. However it’s important to understand that public school teaching is service work more than a career in academia, and people shouldn’t take a PS position without accepting this. Unless you teach only honors academics, you’re likely to have at least a few students who are difficult to teach. Private schools typically offer students who are easier to work with and who are held accountable for what they do. Public schools take all comers and even those they expel have to be given services somewhere.

It depends on what is happening at the school at the moment. Both can be lovely. Both face demands from the organisations that run them. Some private schools are poorer than public schools. Some schools have a vocal parent group. Some schools have an unsupportive parent group. You need to research the individual school. Teachers at both schools can feel stress. It's not straightforward. In the end, it's your department that you need to work with.

They maybe happier because students maybe better behaved however the difference in pay and benefits for me at least outweighs any benefits that a private or parochial school may offer. I rubbed in a Catholic school $65 a day vs. $160 a day as a substitute in public schools. Full time is more of a difference. I had a friend that retired from a Catholic after 20+ years she never made more than $50,000. My 1st year as a full time public school teacher I made $57,000.

Your quality of life will be better. The students will be better behaved. The faculty will be closer. There will be better faculty parties and field trips. The students you teach will be more succesful in life. They will all go to college and most will go to better colleges. There will be more pressure on you give out, not just passing grades, but high grades. Your own kids will probably get free or reduced tuition.
